I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help Armenia improve resilience 
to  the  coronavirus  disease  (COVID-19)  pandemic  and  other  disasters  by  enhancing  and 
operationalizing its distance education system. The TA will (i) support the Ministry of Education, 
Science, Culture and Sport (MESCS) to develop and operationalize a comprehensive distance 
education platform, and (ii) provide capacity building to the selected trainers on the use of the 
distance education system for further dissemination to beneficiaries. 
 
2.   The TA is in country operations business plan for Armenia, 2020–2022 of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) , titled Scaling up Innovation for Education Sector Development.1 The 
scope of the TA was redefined based on the MESCS request2 to respond to the outbreak of the 
COVID-19  pandemic  by  supporting  quality  and  continuous  education  through  a  distance 
education system.3 The TA aligns with Sustainable Development Goal 4 (ensure inclusive and 
equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all) and Strategy 2030's 
guiding principles of promoting innovative technology and providing integrated solutions.4   
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  On 30 January 2020, the World Health Organization declared the COVID-19 outbreak a 
public health emergency of international concern. As of 3 August2020, Armenia had one of the 
highest incidences of COVID-19 globally, with 13,193 cases per 1 million population (compared 
with the global average of 2,354.3) and 257 deaths per 1 million population (compared with the 
global average of 89.2).5 On 16 March 2020, the Government of Armenia declared a state of 
emergency to minimize the risk of COVID-19 infections. Aligning with the actions of many other 
countries, the government closed schools and universities, resulting in the displacement of 
approximately 540,000 learners from their traditional education modality. 
 
4.  Following the state of emergency, Armenia’s entire formal education system shifted to 
online classes using platforms such as Zoom, and other online meeting services. To support 
continuity of education, the MESCS launched a learning materials storage platform on 17 March 
2020 using the website of the National Center for Education Technologies (NCET).6 The platform 
provides learning materials and methodological guidance for teachers, as well as educational 
materials for students. The MESCS’s emergency response includes a mix of digital and non-
digital platforms, social media, website storage, one free-to-air public service TV channel, and 
two cable TV channels. This effort helped to support partial continuity of education. However, it 
revealed many shortcomings in the system that prevented the realization of effective teaching 
and learning for all students. According to the MESCS, 20% of the teachers and students were 
unable to join online classes because of (i) a lack of basic information technology skills, internet

access (despite high-speed internet coverage across the entire country), and devices;7 and (ii) 
the limitations of the current distance learning system, which lacks (a) tools for content integration, 
(b) opportunities for communication exchange between educators and learners, and (c) many 
other functionalities of leading learning management systems. Furthermore, teachers needed to 
have more access to methodological training that prioritized distance learning techniques (e.g., 
use of video, activities, assessments, feedback mechanisms, quizzing), as well as subject matter 
media and other curricula. The MESCS also noted that the country’s strict quarantine which lasted 
an entire academic semester for schools, in combination with a negative health, economic, and 
social outlook in the families of students and teachers, has caused a severe strain and stress that 
is adversely affecting learning outcomes. The United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) has 
provided support for assessing the shift to the emergency online classes, preparing video 
materials, and purchasing prioritized equipment. 
 
5.  Recognizing the importance of providing quality and continued education for all groups in 
the  country,  and  especially  during  the  COVID-19  emergency,  the  MESCS  introduced  an 
amendment to the Law on General Education in March 2020.8 Distance education tools can now 
be used as an alternative to offline education under certain conditions. The MESCS also issued 
a ministerial order in May 2020 to establish a procedure for organizing distance education, 
including the requirements for content, participants, participants’ roles and responsibilities, certain 
conditions when distance education can be used.9 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
6.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: continuous, inclusive, and equitable quality 
education for all public school students of Armenia developed.10 The TA will have the following 
outcome: distance education system improved.11 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
7.  Output 1: Distance education platform developed and launched. The TA will develop, 
test, enhance, and implement a national innovative distance education platform using existing 
and open-source learning management systems with artificial intelligence-assisted features that 
promote more efficient and cost-effective online education delivery. This output will address 
access to education by providing more learning modalities and information in a learner-friendly 
format. The platform will support kindergarten through grade 12 education institutions to deliver 
online courses and support teachers in managing class rosters and posting activities and quizzes, 
readings, materials, and grades. The distance education platform will incorporate the following: (i) 
open-source platforms that use open web standards; have minimal flashy features; are adapted

to the Armenian context and are synchronized with the education management information 
system; and are supported by computer, tablet, and mobile devices; (ii) the use of recorded and 
live-streamed classes to enable student-centric learning, allowing students to preview and study 
recorded videos and online materials (allowing students to then join the live streaming classes 
better  prepared  with  questions,  and  to  interact  with  their  teachers  and  classmates);  (iii) 
communication tools and centralized links, such as Zoom, Google Classroom and Microsoft 
Teams, and communication instruments for educators and learners to support daily learning with 
real-time  feedback  mechanisms;  (iv)  assignment  distribution  and  monitoring;  (v)  a  grading 
platform for improved accessibility, transparency, and monitoring of performance; (vi) integration, 
management, and storage of online content and resources, cataloging existing and new education 
resources, and consolidating the existing locations of the MESCS’s online learning content; and 
(vii) evaluations and assessments, allowing educators to evaluate the impact of courses and 
lessons to show evidence of learning and skill attainment. The distance education platform will 
address the needs and diverse physical capabilities of learners, their caregivers, and teachers. 
The learning materials of the MESCS’s learning materials storage platform (footnote 6) will 
migrate to the new platform after synchronization. As confirmed by the MESCS, the platform 
developed under the TA will be operated and maintained by the NCET. 
 
8.  Output 2: Capacity for the use of distance education platform developed. The TA will 
develop online and offline manuals and guidelines on the use of the distance education platform. 
The training design will pursue the use of the training of trainers methodology to maximize 
innovation, scale, and cost-effectiveness. This output will address teaching quality by increasing 
the capacity of teachers to use an improved distance education platform. The training program 
will incorporate the following approaches: (i) techniques in blended learning; (ii) interactive 
tutorial-based, problem-based training; (iii) activity-based and constructivist approach learning; 
and (iv) techniques for teaching children with special needs. The training of trainers model will be 
used to support post-assistance and post-emergency sustainability. 
 
9.  The TA will also assist the MESCS to develop enabling government policies for providing 
equal opportunities for all teachers, students, and their caregivers to use the platform. In addition, 
the  TA  will  develop  recommendations  for  the  institutional  and  regulatory  aspects  for  the 
maintenance, operation, and upgrades of the platform. The recommendations will include (i) 
funding mechanisms for the platform’s continuous enhancements and upgrades; (ii) the most 
sustainable, efficient, and effective institutional setup; and (iii) the necessary institutional and 
regulatory changes to ensure safe use of data, and support the blended online and offline classes 
as a new approach to education. 
 
10.  Output 3: Targeted distance education content created and refined. The TA will, in 
alignment with outputs 1 and 2, support the development of selected online content of prioritized 
subjects.  In addition, the TA will review the existing distance education curricula, and conduct a 
rapid assessment with MESCS administrators, students, teachers, and caregivers to identify the 
greatest content gaps, which will determine the specific inputs needed for this output. Most of 
these materials will likely be a blend of video formats for rapid rollout and integration into 
Armenia's predominant teacher training methodology. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $800,000 of which $750,000 will be financed, on a grant basis, 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources).  The key expenditure items 
are  listed  in  Appendix  2.  The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of 
counterpart staff, office accommodation, communication facilities, and other in-kind contributions.

4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will administer the TA. The MESCS will be the executing agency. The Armenia 
Resident Mission and the Social Sector Division of the Central and West Asia Department will 
select, supervise, and evaluate consultants. The consultants will procure goods directly for the 
implementation of the TA and organize workshops following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, 
as amended from time to time).

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Armenia for Distance Education for Resilience Project, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.
